definitions.definition: to explain the meaning of something

examples.text: The students were asked to interpret the poem.
The **data** can be **interpreted** in many different ways.
These **results** must be **interpreted** cautiously.
judges who will faithfully interpret the Constitution
These figures cannot be easily interpreted.
We all seek to interpret what we hear and what we read.
The figure of the Ancient Mariner has been variously interpreted.

definitions.definition: to decide that something has a particular meaning and to understand it in this way

examples.text: I didn't know whether to interpret her silence as acceptance or refusal.
The research focused on how parents interpret the behaviour of their toddlers.
Different people might interpret events differently.
The title could be interpreted to mean ‘human intelligence’.
The term ‘business’ is here interpreted broadly to include all types of organization in the public and private sectors.
Her message was interpreted as a warning to the general.
His resignation has been widely interpreted as an admission of his guilt.
The strictness of the rules, even when liberally interpreted, has the effect of restricting innovation.
It is context and convention that determine whether a term will be interpreted literally or metaphorically.

definitions.definition: to translate one language into another as it is spoken

examples.text: He took me with him to interpret in case no one spoke English.
She couldn't speak much English so her children had to interpret for her.
Interpreters must interpret everything that is said in the interaction.

definitions.definition: to perform a piece of music, a role in a play, etc. in a way that shows your feelings about its meaning

examples.text: He interpreted the role with a lot of humour.

wordOrigin: late Middle English: from Old French interpreter or Latin interpretari ‘explain, translate’, from interpres, interpret- ‘agent, translator, interpreter’.
